learning_outcomes.description: Explain the biochemical pathways, processes and concepts underpinning the flow of energy in living systems.
Describe the biochemical pathways, processes and concepts underpinning the flow of information in living systems.
Apply the theory underpinning core practical skills in biochemistry.
Analyse biochemical data using quantitative skills for evaluation, visualisation and interpretation.

assessments.weighting: <dd>25% Each sequential item contributes 5% towards the sequential applied quizzes (total 25%) </dd>
assessments.task_description:
There are many important concepts in biochemistry. Students must practice these and improve their understanding. Tutorial classes are designed to support students' learning and understanding of chemistry. The tutorial class will be structured into two main parts. The first part will be an opportunity for students to work in groups to attempt practice questions, check their responses to questions with tutors, and improve their understanding of concepts covered in previous weeks. The second part will be an in-class quiz assessment, which will be done individually under 'exam-like' conditions. The assessable content of the in-class quiz will be based on topics taught in previous lectures (see Blackboard for more information).

The in-class quiz assessment is a 'closed book' examination conducted under similar conditions as the exams with students allowed "one A4 page typed or hand-written double-sided". Students are required to bring their own UQ approved calculator. Electronic aids (e.g., laptop or phone) are not permitted.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.


Tutorial non-attendanceﾠ

Acceptable evidence for tutorial non-attendance is similar to the evidence required for a deferred examination. The tutorial sessions are timetabled activities, and if students miss a tutorial, they must provide documentation that shows they were unable to attend the tutorial on the relevant day. Documentation for ongoing conditions, such as Student Access Plans, are not acceptable evidence for missed sessions. If approved, options for missed sessions will be discussed with individual students.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Applied quizzes are paper-based assessments carried out in class during your designated tutorial session.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The In-Semester Examination will be an in-person (invigilated) examination covering concepts from week 1 to week 6, conducted as a Central exam (Date TBA) on a Saturday during semester.

Students need to refer to their individual timetable from Central Examinations, which identifies the exam date and time. You will receive a personalised exam timetable from Examinations with the venue identified closer to the examination date.

The exam will be an on-campus exam, at a scheduled on-campus session on a scheduled* date to be arranged. Please ensure you arrive at the venue at least 15 minutes prior to the commencement of your exam. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams. Students enrolled in In Person delivery must attend the exam in-person.

*For Saturday exams, please note a Saturday in-semester exam may be scheduled on 1 of 3 possible dates each semester. Please refer to the Academic Calendar for possible dates, including those approved for a deferred examination.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
You are a biochemistry consultant brought in to investigate reduced growth and inconsistent feed outcomes at a mixed forage–ruminant farm.

Farm management suspects one of three possible biochemical causes:

  • Hypothesis 1 — Heat-related digestive/metabolic constraint
  • Enzyme activity may be impaired under high temperatures.
  • Hypothesis 2 — Fermentation bottleneck from low WSC/poor forage
  • Microbial energy supply (VFAs) may be limited due to plant stress.
  • Hypothesis 3 — Parasite burden affecting nutrient absorption & metabolism
  • GI parasite load may be draining protein/energy and increasing oxidative stress.


Your task

  • Using your four practical datasets (P1–P4), determine which hypothesis is best supported by evidence, and recommend what the farmer should do next.


Required Structure (see course Blackboard site for a detailed breakdown of the requirements for each section)

  • Problem Statement (≤150 words)
  • Evidence Table (1 page max)
  • Hypothesis Evaluation (300–400 words)
  • Decision & Recommended Action (≤200 words)
  • Figures & Data


Marking Criteria (see course Blackboard site for detailed marking criteria)

A. Evidence Table Quality (20% marks)

B. Quantitative Interpretation (20% marks)

C. Mechanistic Reasoning (30% marks)

D. Integration & Decision Quality (20% marks)

E. Recommendations (10% marks)


Laboratory practical class attendance

Students are required to attend the practical sessions. This is clearly indicated on the timetable and the course Blackboard site. If, due to any unforeseen circumstances, the practical timetable needs to be changed, students will be informed in advance. If you do not attend a practical class or do not provide evidence of your attendance (i.e. student ID scan on arrival, signing the attendance sheet and getting a tutor's endorsement on your task sheet), you will lose marks as set out in the marking criteria on Blackboard.


Absence from a Practical Session 

If you are unable to complete your timetabled practical session because of circumstances beyond your control (e.g., illness) you must submit a practical absence request immediately accompanied by acceptable supporting documentation.  

 A list of acceptable reasons and required supporting documentation is found at https://my.uq.edu.au/information-and-services/manage-my-program/exams-and-assessment/applying-assessment-extension?p=1#1  

Your request must be submitted prior to or on the day of the missed practical. The submission link can be found in the Learning Resources (Blackboard Original) or Course Resources (Blackboard Ultra) folder in your course Blackboard site.  

Requests without the correct supporting documentation may not be approved. If the reason for your absence is not approved, you will be considered absent from that practical session.  

It is your responsibility to submit an application and provide correct documentation.  

  • If there is an associated assessment item, you must submit the relevant assessment item by the due date. If the reason for your absence impacts your ability to meet the due date, you must apply for an extension of assessment due date.  
  • There may be opportunities to reschedule you into a later practical session within the week. Please contact the course coordinator to discuss alternative practical session availability. 
  • If you require access to restricted online resources such as videos to complete your assessment, you must contact the course coordinator to get access to the online resources.

 If you require further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact the School - agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au.  


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture Series

Lecture 1 Introduction + Metabolic Integration (Dr Suresh Krishnasamy)

Lecture 2 Enzymes & Regulation (Dr Suresh Krishnasamy)

Lecture 3 Lipid Metabolism & Ketosis (Dr Suresh Krishnasamy)

Lecture 4 Protein & Nitrogen Metabolism (Dr Suresh Krishnasamy)

Lecture 5 Parasitology through the Biochemistry Lens (Dr Anne Beasley)

Lecture 6 Microbial Fermentation (Associate Professor Sarah Meale)

Lecture 7 Herbicides + ROS + Antioxidants (Dr Jhoana Opena + Dr Suresh Krishnasamy)

Lecture 8 DNA, Gene Expression & Regulation (Dr Nick Hudson)

Lecture 9 Molecular Tools in Agriculture (Dr Nick Hudson)

Lecture 10 Stress Biochemistry (Dr Angela Lees)

Lecture 11 Silage Biochemistry (tbc)

Lecture 12 Bent Bananas (Associate Professor Anthony Young)

Lecture 13 Revision (Dr Suresh Krishnasamy)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
